Topic.Title: Intel planning new devices unit led by former Apple exec

Message.Msg: The big picture here is that Intel is funding innovation. Apple took itself out of the leadership role a couple of years ago. The industry has certainly needed investment and leadership in this area. While Intel really can't be the next Apple since its not a consumer products company the point is clear that a few mildly successful new products can change the fortune of Intel. For years Intel has been investing five years out or further in R&D. Very few companies can afford to do this. The question is why has it taken Intel this long to be in this position? It wasn't too long ago that Intel was working at full capacity and perhaps had products on allocation. With all it's new volume Intel is signaling that it wants to be more than a me too commodity SoC player that others on here have predicted. Also, five years ago Steve Jobs was alive and in charge of the helm of Apple's destiny. Had he lived industry leadership in innovation would have been much harder with Apple able to seize on new innovations better than anybody else in the industry. What you are seeing right now is a leaderless industry with slightly modified versions of the same stuff we've had for the last three years. The industry is craving change.

Message.Title: Tizen: Meet the Asian Android-Killer From Intel and Samsung
Message.Msg: Tizen: Meet the Asian Android-Killer From Intel and Samsung By André Mouton Mar 18, 2013 9:00 am Tizen will retain Android's more desirable features, like the low price tag and the cross-compatibility between markets, but it will also leave room for regional adaptation. 37 37 PrintPRINT 2 Comments URGENT BUY ALERT: Top 12 Stocks for 2013 - FREE! Click Now! Stay Connected Twitter Facebook Google + RSS Feed Tizen, the new mobile OS from Samsung (KRX:005930) and Intel (NASDAQ:INTC), is a lot like Android (NASDAQ:GOOG). Both operating systems are open source and Linux-based. They look and feel about the same, and smartphone users won’t have any problem switching between the two. Their logos, however, suggest a difference. When Google chose a personable green robot to represent Android, it was selling the system’s intelligence, with its integrated "brain" of Google Web apps and services. Tizen, on the other hand, is portrayed as a pinwheel – a toy that spins in whatever direction the wind is blowing. In other words, it’s a platform that doesn’t discriminate. Android has had a remarkably successful run in the four years since it debuted. Today, it comes on about half of the smartphones sold globally. In emerging markets, though – and Asia in particular – this success has been an awkward one. Google might be the dominant search engine and Web services provider in the US and Europe, but across the Pacific, that position is held by the likes of Baidu (NASDAQ:BIDU), Naver (KRX:035420), and Yahoo Japan (TYO:4689). Google’s Web apps are not always available, and when they are, they’re not generally preferred. The fact that Android is free, and has a large application base, means that manufacturers have adopted it anyway, but they’ve been forced to offer customized versions that strip away the Google content and replace it with less native content. samsung tizen The situation has become particularly bad in Chi

Message.Title: 6 Reasons Why The iPhone Will Soon Have Processors Built By Intel
Message.Msg: [Crazier things have happened. We will know more when we see which way the iWatch deal breaks...] Six reasons why the iPhone will soon have processors built by Intel: Apple (AAPL) needs to have the best technology to continue to provide cutting edge products and to be able to charge the premium it has charged in the past. Intel (INTC) needs to put its processors in smartphones. The smartphone market is growing rapidly. Intel will make more money by building the iPhone processor than not. Intel will soon have excess capacity in its fabs (semiconductor chip factories). Apple will pay less per processor buying from Intel, compared to its current supplier Samsung (SSNLF.PK), or its other alternative TSMC (TSM). Apple and Intel would both find strategic advantages in such a deal. Despite the widespread belief that Intel is a microprocessor company, its distinguishing characteristic is that it is a leader in the manufacturing of integrated circuits. Intel's microprocessor design division is really just a way to ensure its fabs are full of high value semiconductors. I have listed six reasons why this will eventually occur, but I have not specified the processor. Two scenarios exist: Scenario 1. Apple could put an Intel designed Atom processor in the iPhone, or Scenario 2. Intel could act as a foundry for the A series, and produce those Apple designed A series (A7 or A8) for the iPhones. The six reasons above apply to both scenarios. More details on the six reasons are listed below. By Jim Brody

people are figuring out that the developing world smart phone purchases are growing by triple digits. these phones are sub-$100 phones. INTC is in these phones. INTC is entering Tablets. INTC owns PCs, which are not dead by a long shot. Haswell will own tablets and phones. By early 2016, INTC will be in every PC, tablet, phone, watch, etc... while still being ahead by at least one generation in fabrication, not even counting the advantage 450mm wafers will bring. we will see a P/E adjustment soon along with a forward looking EPS, not ttm. IMHO.

The Galaxy Tab win, if confirmed, is sooo important. It means Intel won't have to really fight to get into the best selling mobile vendor outside of Apple. just needs to keep producing the best mobile processor every new year and it could be used. The ARM mobile market is basically split amongst the cheap small die chips at the low end and the highest performance chips at the high end. The low-end market Intel can attack with its n-1 process chips, e.g. Clovertrail+ when Silvermont arrives, by selling at wafer cost and the n process chips like Silvermont can attack the high end. Every year the mobile device vendors demand a superior performing chip to last year's model, so far ARM has fulfilled this need by going A8, dual-core A9, quad-core A9, quad-core A15. What is it going to do for next year though ? Is either 20nm or A57 ready ? This leaves an opportunity for Intel to move in with quad-core Silvermont if neither are ready in volume. Maybe TSMC's 20nm might be ready for volume in 2014 but will Samsung's considering they need to switch to gate-last at the same time ? I would say there is a strong possibility that the Samsung Galaxy S5 will contain a quad-core Silvermont if a 20nm Extnos Octa is not ready in time which will be some volume !

Message.Title: Incoming Intel CEO Not Wasting Time – Sweeping Changes Coming
Message.Msg: New Intel CEO Brian Krzanich is wasting no time reorganizing the chip-giant Intel. Just a week in to his new position at Intel, Krzanich announced a “sweeping company reorganization” in an internal memo on Monday, according to Reuters. Among the changes is the creation of a “new devices” unit that will develop mobile chipsets quicker in order to become more competitive with Qualcomm, a chip manufacturer for smartphones and tablets. “The group will be tasked with turning cool technology and business model innovations into products that shape and lead markets,” Krzanich said in a statement. PCMag is reporting the head of the “new devices” department will be former executive of Apple and Palm, Mike Bell, who currently co-heads the mobile chip unit. The restructuring is part of Intel’s plan to become more dominant in the mobile device market, which it has had a difficult time breaking into. Rumors have been circulating that Intel will partner with Apple and become a producer of Apple’s A7 chips. If true, this could help bolster Intel’s standing in the mobile market, though market experts point out that ARM-based processors (not the A7) currently dominate the marketplace. Intel spokesman Chuck Mulloy told PCMag: “The primary objective is to move faster, not just with the Intel architecture, not just with mobile, but across the entire company and to be able to move faster into markets as we see them develop.” From highlightpress

Message.Title: Former Apple Exec To Head Intel’s New Devices Unit
Message.Msg: Intel is in the process of shaking things up. One big change in the wings is the addition of a new devices unit. Today, AllThingsD is reporting that former Apple executive Mike Bell will be in charge of the new development department. Currently, Bell heads Intel’s mobile chip unit alongside Hermann Eul. When Bell switches to running the new devices unit, Eul will take over the mobile chip department. According to Intel’s new CEO, Brian Krzanich, the new unit will be researching emerging technologies and trending products. “The group will be tasked with turning cool technology and business model innovations into products that shape and lead markets,” Krzanich said in a statement. Reuters recently reported on Intel’s creation of the new devices unit. The reorganization comes only a few days after Krzanich took office. According to unnamed sources who spoke with Reuters, Intel’s new CEO said that the company will be more responsive to customers with an “intensified focus” on the mobile device market. Intel has had a difficult time breaking into the mobile device market. Recent rumors have pointed to a possible partnership with Apple. However, ARM-based processors currently lead the market. If the rumor is true that Intel will be contracted to produce some of Apple’s A7 chips, it could help increase the former’s presence in the market. “The new devices organization is responsible for rapidly turning brilliant technical and business model innovations into products that shape and lead markets,” Krzanich said. From appadvice

Message.Title: Apple Unlikely To Move To Intel Chips For iPad Or iPhone?
Message.Msg: If Apple's only problem was that forthcoming tablets and smartphones made with Intel chips were simply speedier, as in more MIPs or FLOPS I could agree with Eassa's argument,. Apple could conceivably employ a custom ARM with mediocre speed bolted with fast graphics capability and try to compete. But speed is not the only dimension Intel has gained advantage. Intel-based tablets and smartphones should also enjoy far better battery life and while most consumers are ignorant about MIPS and FLOPS they are very well aware of battery life and how long they can go between having to charge up. The other key differentiator is software. Tablets with Intel processors can run professional 64 bit Windows AND Android. This gives Intel tablets the enormous distinction of offering the user access to the millions of mature apps in the Windows ecosystem plus everything Android has to offer. While iPad is just iOS, with no access to MAC OS. The software distinction will be most visible on tablets initially but what Intel does for tablets this year, they will do to smartphones very soon. Every day Apple delays getting on board the Intel train they will find themselves becoming less and less competitive in a sea of faster, better, and cheaper products with superior battery life and far broader software capability.

INTC with its volume and solid base can shrug off bad analyst sentiment but not a fluff stock like ARMH. I always thought it would be a combination of bad analyst sentiment, bad earnings/forecast and good Intel news that would bring it down to Earth. Well the first and last are starting the decline but when they have bad earnings or forecast that will really start the avalanche like it did with AAPL.

Topic.Title: Apple Unlikely To Move To Intel Chips For iPad Or iPhone?

Message.Msg: While I fully understand the "not invented here" syndrome I believe Apple has a greater responsibility to do what's best for its customers and shareholders. From my perspective switching to Intel is not an action designed to insult anyone, it's simply a necessary step to keep the company relevant. There are many ways to reward significant contribution by talented employees other than perpetual employment. BTW, I enjoy your articles.

I don't think Intel will go the other way (fab services for an Apple-tweaked ARM design). At least - I don't think they should (IMHO).

This was the last msg on ARM board ... The importance of being rooted ARM is strongly rooted in mobile and at the low power end of the microprocessor market. That means its got all its weight on on foot in the paint and it can pivot from here if needed. Intel will likely challenge it in low power, but it can equally make inroads at the higher power end of the market. It's not going away anytime soon. It's staying power is what gives Intel nightmares. None of Intel's previous competitors had this vantage point when looking at Intel.

Topic.Title: Apple Unlikely To Move To Intel Chips For iPad Or iPhone?

Message.Msg: Again Apples failure to innovate and adapt may end up being it's downfall. Just good enough ARM, will NOT be good enough. Apple ignores intel technology at its own peril. Apple should heed the lesson learnt by intel. Don't tell the market or consumer what they should have. Listen to the market and produce products that the market want. Clearly the market will want convertible Tablet PC's. I know this because a lady friend of mine, who is a huge Macbook fan and totally technology illeterate, said the other day there are new notebooks coming out that double as tablets. I was surprised by comments from her. Guess what, little does she know, apple has decided that iPad is just good enough for her needs?

Topic.Title: Apple Unlikely To Move To Intel Chips For iPad Or iPhone?

Message.Msg: What makes you think Apple is not already working with Intel to switch to Intel processor possibly both Atom (in smaller devices) and Core in full-sized iPads, basically, similar to the MS Surface Pro, but better implemented by Apple than by MS as usual. I love it how people write in blogs and postings about how Apple needs to consider switching to Intel processors as if that is some huge insight that Apple never considered and is not already doing. We now know that Apple even wanted Intel to foundry the chips for the original iPhone, but Intel declined because what Apple was willing to pay per unit was deemed too little. Also, of course, at that time Apple had recently converted Macs to Intel. So, I am sure that using Intel chips for iOS devices has never been far from Apple's attention and that they have been working in secret with Intel to make that conversion by 2014 or maybe even Fall of 2013 with the next generation of iPads. That would be nice, but my expectation is to see the switch in 2014. Either way, good for Apple and HUGE for Intel. That is why I am long long term both AAPL and INTC. I have owned AAPL since 2006 when they converted to Intel processors in Mac and well before the iPhone was even a rumor. And I have owned Intel since 2003 taking the opportunity to buy after the crash and adding as Intel began paying larger and larger dividends. I expect nice increases in both INTC and AAPL in 2014 and maybe even later this year. But I can wait. I'll just bide my time counting the money I am collecting from INTC and AAPL dividends.
What makes you believe they are changing their dividend policy?

Topic.Title: Eassa needs to get his head out of his rump and do some talk over in the valley.

Message.Msg: Welcome to "ignore".
Actually - before- I did not think they would change it myself. However - they usually announce the increase early May, but they didn't. Perhaps they will delay the increase for a quarter.?.
i subscribed to them.

Topic.Title: Apple Unlikely To Move To Intel Chips For iPad Or iPhone?

Message.Msg: Intel is my highest conviction long position, and I think they will do very well in mobile devices. But Apple seems hell bent - from aggressive hiring of CPU teams, to what I've heard of them trying to poach Intel CPU engineers (I do have friends at Intel who have been contacted by Apple) - on keeping its CPU/SoC designs in-house.

Not really early May. It seems more like mid to late May so I would not read too much into it. Additionally, if you look back over the last four years or so, they don't always announce increases on a regular annual schedule. Intel's dividend and buyback policy is based on returning a percentage of cash flow. I think it is targeted as 40% of cash flow. Unless the cash flow has stopped increasing, I would not expect the dividend payments to stop increasing.

Topic.Title: Apple Unlikely To Move To Intel Chips For iPad Or iPhone?

Message.Msg: No-one wants to run PC apps on tablets or smartphones. The way you design an app for these form factors is completely different. For starters, you target the installed base which is mostly iOS or Android running ARM. It's going to be very difficult to suddenly change the installed base. Apple just needs to make their products incrementally better to stay in business which they are slotted to do without needing to change their underlying microprocessor.

Message.Title: HP could care less about PC/hardware
Message.Msg: Their PC numbers were horrible..down over 20%, yet the stock up 13% AHs. Thats the problem with Intel. They need PC/server volumse to increase, but the OEMs care most about services/software & dont mind losing in hardware. Intel needs to sell direct to consumers/businesses.

Topic.Title: Apple Unlikely To Move To Intel Chips For iPad Or iPhone?

Message.Msg: Perhaps. But I also think it is possible that Intel would foundry Apple's "A" chip design. Apple could work with Intel to optimize the design to best utilize the trigate advantages (or maybe not, I'm certainly no microprocessor architect). I disagree with those who say Intel would not foundry an ARM-based chip for Apple. If the money is right, why wouldn't they? Also, if Apple is hiring Intel CPU engineers, maybe that is an indication that Apple IS planning to switch to Intel designs. Who better to help with a transition to Intel x86 processors than former Intel engineers? And why hire those guys to design ARM-based processors. I know people at Intel and Intel has an "Apple Group" within the company. They only work on Apple projects and they keep what they are working on a secret even from other Intel employees outside the Apple group. The rumor is that they are working on an x86 based iPad. But even before I hear that, I knew it made sense. Apple and Intel have something cooking (no Tim Cook pun intended), you can count on it. Don't forget that they have successfully kept their collaborations a secret before. The announcement of Macs switching to Intel caught everyone by surprise. Then they surprised everyone again at MacWorld by demonstrating iMacs and MacBook Pros running on Intel Core processors (which were new then) a full six months ahead of the schedule they had announced at WWDC in the prior June. Then even the MacBook Air was a collaboration with Intel to make a custom chipset package to fit the super-thin design that was also kept a secret. So just because there is little more than speculation, that does not mean they have not been working on, at least, an x86 iPad. Both Intel and Apple have shown before that can keep these kinds of secrets.

Topic.Title: Apple Unlikely To Move To Intel Chips For iPad Or iPhone?

Message.Msg: Apple is in year two of it's post Jobs identity crises. Year one came without stockholders and the board of directors breathing down Tim Cook's back. Those days are past and Cook is feeling the heat. Apple has lot the title of being the innovation leader. If they blow it with phones they will struggle to keep relevant. Their previous plans of thinking that the user experience trumps hardware innovation just isn't working in their favor. I won't say that they "have not choice but to work with Intel." They have lots of choices. They can choose to watch their stock drop and Tim Cook could choose to be forced out. When you're battle plans include Samsung, no, TSMC as your partner to battle Intel it's time to seriously think about the future.

Topic.Title: HP could care less about PC/hardware

Message.Msg: They already do. A couple of quarters ago I recall them mentioning on the conference call that more and more of there server business is with companies buying motherboards for rack-server systems directly from Intel to install in the servers themselves rather than buying servers from Dell, HP, and other OEMs. It seems unlikely that Intel would ever sell computers directly. The margins are too low. Making the processors is the most profitable part of the chain. Getting into building and selling finished computers just takes them into low profit areas. That is why HP does not care, as you said. But if HP's numbers are down, that does not mean total PC sales must go down. Lenovo and Acer will happily take over what HP does not want. And Intel will sell more to them.

Topic.Title: Apple Unlikely To Move To Intel Chips For iPad Or iPhone?

Message.Msg: How do you know Apple is ignoring Intel technology? I guess they forgot to inform you that they are working with Intel on an x86 based iPad. How inconsiderate of them.

Topic.Title: Apple Unlikely To Move To Intel Chips For iPad Or iPhone?

Message.Msg: I just realized that you are the guy whose articles I read on Seeking Alpha. I like your analysis of Intel in those Seeking Alpha articles, but as I said, I disagree on this point. I think Intel and Apple have a BIG surprise in the works. And as I said, the poaching of Intel engineers by Apple that you mentioned may be an indicator that Apple really is going to switch to Intel designed chips. As I also said, who better to manage that transition than the guys who actually worked on those Intel designs and how much good would they be for working on ARM-based designs. You might reconsider how you are interpreting Apple poaching of Intel CPU engineers. Give it some thought. Thanks.

Topic.Title: Apple Unlikely To Move To Intel Chips For iPad Or iPhone?

Message.Msg: Thank you for your response. It is very much appreciated. Great discussion :)

It is worth noting that Apple has been Intel's most loyal x86 processor customer. Every other computer OEM uses AMD chips as well as Intel and they also use many of Intel's lower margin celeron processors. Only Apple uses 100% Intel processor in their computers and, more than that, they only use Core i5, i7, and i9 and they even use two Xeons per Mac Pro system. They don't buy any of Intel's cheap, low margin Celerons. Apple computers are 100% Intel and use only the most current top-of-the-line processor models. That sounds like a pretty good customer to me. Apple even asked Intel to make the iPhone processors, but Intel declined. So I see no evidence that Apple will not stick by Intel. And what the hell is the deal with this "AAPL is worse than any jewish outfit" garbage? Grow up. We don't need your kind here.

Topic.Title: Apple Unlikely To Move To Intel Chips For iPad Or iPhone?

Message.Msg: You're welcome.

Topic.Title: Apple Unlikely To Move To Intel Chips For iPad Or iPhone?

Message.Msg: According to Qualcom TriGate/FinFet requires complete redesign when switching from (20nm) planar to 3D. IOW Apple can't just plug a 20nm design into a 14nm manufacturing process. (that's why ALTR has to stick with TSMC @ 20nm but go with Intel @ 14nm) Apple would waste precious time sticking too long with TSMC - the only way to leapfrog Samsung would be to go with Intel
So you're an anti-Semite. Dunce.

Message.Title: Trade Idea: Short ARM Holdings on Samsung design loss
Message.Msg: Trade idea background ARM Holdings' stock is down in early London trading following news that Samsung may use Intel's Atom processor in their Galaxy Tab 3. This could mark the end of the "free lunch" ARM Holdings has had with Intel being behind the curve on mobile device processors. ARM Holdings is extremely overvalued based on the EV/TIC framework with the enterprise value being GBP 13.8 billion on GBP 1.1 billion in total invested capital. This premium valuation does not hold up with the profitability spread, defined as the ROIC vs. WACC, which is only around 1.5x. In other words, the valuation does not reflect the underlying profitability and expectations are too rosy. If the momentum reverses on the news of design loss to Intel then long investors might be willing to get out causing prices to correct downward over the foreseeable future. Trade management and risk description The trade is entered as a short market order with a stop at 1,075 and target at 900. The biggest risk to this trade is either counter news on the rumours of design loss or better than expected macro data. Tomorrow better than expected PMI figures for Europe could ignite a broad run-up in stocks yet again which would lift ARM Holdings despite the negative news stream. Trade idea parameters Entry: Short market order From Peter Garnry, Head of Equity Strategy, Saxo Bank

Message.Title: Another Comment From the UK ARMH Message Board
Message.Msg: But I am now getting more nervous about Intel. The claims they're making for Silvermont are pretty remarkable - although the Intel slide on the following page is interesting. I've read in many places, as on this page, that Silvermont (the next Atom) will bring 3 times performance at 5 times lower power consumption. That's widely reported. But the slide actually seems to show 3 times performance or 5 times lower power consumption. That sounds more realistic - but is still very hefty. Given the current Atom is close to the performance of an A15, having that performance at 5 times less power would be very attractive. I've been surprised the market hasn't moved in reaction to this - maybe no one believes Intel. When the first independent benchmarks come out, be ready to sell (some, anyway). Having already seen a slide from 1000p to 100p, now we're back again I'm not sure I'm ready for another.

Message.Title: HERE'S THE BOTTOM LINE
Message.Msg: 1) APPLE AND SAMSUNG ARE AT WAR with each other. 2) Intel is rolling out Silvermont - Bay Trail for tablets and Merrifield for smartphones. Bay Trail and Merrifield are the best performing SoCs with best battery life. 3) BOTTOM LINE: Either one or both will strike a deal with Intel to use Bay Trail/Merrifield in their products. Anyone who thinks otherwise is in denial.

Message.Title: ARM Holdings plc will be hosting ANALYST and INVESTOR presentations TODAY in London.
Message.Msg: ARM HOLDINGS PLC - "ANALYST AND INVESTOR DAY" That was yesterday. So, what would you conclude when the stock of a company drops 8 percent in the 2 days beginning with its Analyst and Investor Day presentation? The sky is falling. On ARM...
